Reminder about #UCBerkeley: 2 things can be true at the same time. That violence is wrong and Milo's brand of harassment needs to be stopped
Basically by dealing with the other adults in the room, not directly engaging with him or his band of trolls. #stopMilo
Irrelevant: by organizing competing events. Boycotting the brands he uses or promotes. Boycotting the editorials that give him book deals.
Milo won't be stopped with riots. Those empower him. The only way to stop him is by turning him irrelevant.
And Trump wins too, because he gets to bully a whole campus for the actions of a few (reminds of his approach to terrorism).
But Milo wins when violence erupts. He gets attention (his currency) and the chance to appear victimized, distracting from his awful record.
I know libertarians. Milo Yiannopoulos is not that. Unless libertarians are now misogynistic bullies that use free speech to harass people.
And that's how you break up with fitness, ask me anything. https://t.co/IG5SQsLT0v

Given that the "comedian" on this year's WH correspondents dinner will probably be Jesse Watters, this is good: https://t.co/XJuklBIhE9
@cristalmarie Now imagine how much worse it is for Muslims. Or those who were flying out of the banned countries when the ban got signed ðŸ˜¢
And that we're needed in the fight to keep it that way.
(...) to hold a sign so that a little nobody like me (and tons of Muslim immigrants) remember that this country is so much more than Trump.
And that's what makes this country already great: that there's people who are willing to drive out to Dulles (...)
After the newly hostile demeanor of customs agents, that reception was the most moving thing I've ever experienced.
I was doing ok until a sign that simply said "We're happy you're here" sent me over the edge and I started weeping.
They're singing "this land is your land." There are lawyers offering pro bono services to people that get detained or held up for no reason.
Hundreds of people were chanting "Love trumps hate" and holding signs that said 'welcome' in many languages, mostly Arabic.
Finally I walked out, hands still shaking from nerves. And outside the door was this: #dulles #IAD https://t.co/Yj4oYcxeE6
I asked if everything was ok when he went for a long time without saying anything. He shrugged and said "new rules," whatever that means.
In all my years of traveling into the U.S. this was a 1st: they don't usually ask that much. Before, they focused on keeping lines moving.
I was nervous and kept stammering while the agent asked all sort of things, including a lot of questions about my job.
Lines were extra long, considering agents are now asking a lot more questions than usual.
Long, weepy thread coming your way: I just made it through customs at Dulles.
From the guy that pushed the #Pizzagate lie to all his followers: https://t.co/5ceU7AaS0I
About to board a plane headed to DC, which I now call home. I've never been more scared to go through customs.
